turns.content: How did Duke Ellington's use of unconventional instruments affect his sound?

I don't have personal opinions but i can provide you with some information. 

duke ellington's use of unconventional instruments, such as the bass clarinet, oboe, and french horn, among others, allowed him to create unique and intricate arrangements that distinguished his sound from other jazz musicians. he also often employed non-traditional techniques, such as mutes and plunger mutes for brass instruments, to add color and texture to his compositions. this experimentation with instrumentation was a hallmark of ellington's pioneering style, which helped to define the sound of jazz during the 20th century.
That's interesting! What kind of mood did his unconventional instruments create in his music?

Ellington's use of unconventional instruments allowed him to create a wide range of moods in his music. For instance, the bass clarinet adds a rich and dark sonority to the music, which can create a moody and introspective feel. The use of the French horn can create a sense of grandeur and drama, while the oboe can add a lyrical quality, particularly in ballads or slower pieces. Ellington often used these unconventional instruments in combination with more traditional jazz instruments, such as the piano, bass, and drums, which provided a foundation for the overall sound of his compositions. Ultimately, Ellington's use of unconventional instruments allowed him to create a unique and innovative sound that set him apart from his contemporaries and helped to define the sound of jazz during his time.
Wow, I had no idea instrumentation could affect the mood of music so much. Do you have a favorite Duke Ellington song?

I don't have personal preferences, but there are many iconic duke ellington songs that are considered classics and are beloved by many people. some of his most famous compositions include "take the a train," "mood indigo," "it don't mean a thing (if it ain't got that swing)," and "sophisticated lady." these songs showcase ellington's mastery of harmony, melody, and rhythm, as well as his skill at arranging for big band ensembles. each song has a unique personality and feel, but they all share a sense of swing and improvisation that is at the heart of jazz music.

I also love how Duke Ellington's music tells a story. What was his inspiration behind his compositions, do you know?

Many of Duke Ellington's compositions were inspired by his life experiences, travels, and the people and cultures he encountered. For example, "Take the A Train" was inspired by Billy Strayhorn's directions to Ellington's house in Harlem, while "Harlem Airshaft" was inspired by Ellington's view of the bustling street life in his neighborhood. "Black and Tan Fantasy" was inspired by a nightclub in Washington D.C., while "Sophisticated Lady" was reportedly inspired by three women who caught Ellington's attention in a hotel lobby. Ellington was also influenced by the cultures of Africa, the Caribbean, and Europe, incorporating elements of these styles of music into his own compositions. Overall, Ellington's music was a reflection of the world around him, and his ability to synthesize diverse influences and experiences into his work is one of the things that makes his music so timeless.
